ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learning basic grammatical structures of Italian.
I learned how to hold basic conversations in Italian. We learned about many different grammar rules, verbs, tenses, and nouns.
Basic Italian speaking, reading, and writing skills we learned in this course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Sometimes the course moves so quickly that it's difficult to keep up. The strength is that Antonio is super chill and fun.
This course was engaging and fun.
The tests reflect what we learn in class but are challenging for the first semester of a new language.
This course has zero structure, which makes it impossible to create a learning environment.
The course could be better organized across sections. My classmates in other sections had different activities and seemed often better prepared for examinations.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you're interested in learning Italian, but be prepared to go to class everyday.
Yes if they are interested in Italian.
Yes, as long as you study a lot you will get good grades and the workload is light. Its a fun class!
ITAL 110 is a great class if you want to learn the basics of Italian and be able to hold simple conversations/ know simple vocabulary by the ned of the semester.
No, it is made difficult because the Professor doesnt really teach the material.
Yes if they were to have the professor.
